content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Let <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the polar curve given by <math alttext="r of theta equals, 2 plus, the sine of, open parenthesis, 3 times theta, close parenthesis, times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 3 times theta, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="r of theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>θ</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in units and <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in radians. The graph of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure. (a) Find the area of the region enclosed by the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Let <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the polar curve given by <math alttext="r of theta equals, 2 plus, the sine of, open parenthesis, 3 times theta, close parenthesis, times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 3 times theta, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="r of theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>θ</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in units and <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in radians. The graph of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure. (a) Find the area of the region enclosed by the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find the average distance from the origin to a point on the polar curve <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to the fraction pi over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Find the rate of change of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> with respect to <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> at the point on the polar curve <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> where <math alttext="theta equals, the fraction 4 pi over 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>. Find the slope of the line tangent to the polar curve <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at the point where <math alttext="theta equals, the fraction 4 pi over 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>.

(d) A particle is moving along the polar curve <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math> so that <math alttext="the derivative of theta with respect to t, equals 1.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> radians per second for all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds. Find the value of <math alttext="the derivative of r with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="theta equals, the fraction 3 pi over 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Interpret the meaning of your answer in terms of the motion of the particle.

topic.text: 8.1: Finding the Average Value of a Function on an Interval

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
